title: desouza420
author: desouza420
content: Hey everybodyis it a wise idea to use my gaming pc for mining?i am thinking of buying a mining rig but i want to wait till August and you all know the reasonand in the meantime i am thinking of using my PC for mining for a few monthsi have a GeForce 1050 TI using nicehash for miningany ideas for coins/pools or solo mining are welcome

comments.author: JayDDee
comments.body: Quote from: desouza420 on May 29, 2022, 04:10:36 PMHey everybodyis it a wise idea to use my gaming pc for mining?i am thinking of buying a mining rig but i want to wait till August and you all know the reasonand in the meantime i am thinking of using my PC for mining for a few monthsi have a GeForce 1050 TI using nicehash for miningany ideas for coins/pools or solo mining are welcome 1050ti is no longer suitable for mining Eth. You can play with it mining other coins and get a feel for mining, but you won't make any moneywith it. Build slow, buy a new GPU for your PC and mine with it, then expand to a mining rig later.

comments.author: Maliceprime
comments.body: Keep using the GTX 1050Ti till you get some miners and I like the idea of buying the miners in August and that's even if graphic cards loses more value, use the below calculator to find the most profitable pool for your gpu but 1050 ti is too low end. Be expecting 0.30$ to 0.50$ https://minerstat.com/hardware/nvidia-gtx-1050ti

comments.author: rdluffy
comments.body: Waiting until August is a good idea if you don't have any more cards / rigs right now.With your 1050ti you can use with Nicehash to mine and receive in BTC, I don't know which algo is more profitable with a 1050ti (probably not profitable if you are paying for electricity) but can teach you some things to get used if you decided to mount a rig after your decision in August.You can learn how to mine, overclock, temperature, payments, crypto etc, but don't expect profits, cryptos are in a bear market and it's almost not profitable to most of us home/small miners.

Build slow, buy a new GPU for your PC and mine with it, then expand to a mining rig later.I agree now that the price of for example the Rtx 2060 Super 8 Gb is good enough to just test the waters and see for yourself.I would also suggest this journey/learning path,just upgrade your video card and see for yourself for a couple of months,if you like what you see,then most probably you can go ahead and build a full mining rig.

comments.author: Cuda911
comments.body: Nothing beats cheap graphic cards for mining long term, use your present GPU for some practice, pools and stuffs then when the right time comes you will be able to buy 700$ GPU in bull market for 300$, look forward to that.

comments.author: OgNasty
comments.body: Quote from: Cuda911 on May 30, 2022, 01:13:47 PMNothing beats cheap graphic cards for mining long term, use your present GPU for some practice, pools and stuffs then when the right time comes you will be able to buy 700$ GPU in bull market for 300$, look forward to that.Mostly my advice piggybacking on this would be to make sure that you spend USD and not BTC on your GPUs.  That's the best way in my opinion to achieve ROI, otherwise you'll be looking at the BTC price and wishing you had just held in a few years.  Spending USD to buy miners has always been the winning move in crypto in my opinion and the biggest stings I've had in my crypto experience is spending BTC and not buying more to replace it immediately.  Then you get mad at start looking for people to blame.  Save yourself the trouble and spend you fiat to mine crypto.

comments.author: MinerPath
comments.body: Quote from: desouza420 on May 29, 2022, 04:10:36 PMHey everybodyis it a wise idea to use my gaming pc for mining?i am thinking of buying a mining rig but i want to wait till August and you all know the reasonand in the meantime i am thinking of using my PC for mining for a few monthsi have a GeForce 1050 TI using nicehash for miningany ideas for coins/pools or solo mining are welcome Using the hardware you already have for mining is always a good idea in my opinion.Yes, 1050Ti probably won't make you more than $10-15 per month, but you will learn how to mine with various apps and/or on various pools.And if you invest those $10-15 per month smart, within two years you may have $300-400, which if invested properly may turn to $3000-4000(we all know why in 2 years ).

comments.author: avikz
comments.body: Quote from: desouza420 on May 29, 2022, 04:10:36 PMHey everybodyis it a wise idea to use my gaming pc for mining?i am thinking of buying a mining rig but i want to wait till August and you all know the reasonand in the meantime i am thinking of using my PC for mining for a few monthsi have a GeForce 1050 TI using nicehash for miningany ideas for coins/pools or solo mining are welcome If you had thought about it back in 2009 to 2016, you would have became a millionaire by now. However, for now, your configuration is not suitable for mining anymore. So I would suggest you not to burn your system by mining. Rather get a mining rig for that purpose. I have a 1660ti and it just produces 27 mh/s. I have tried mining ETH using it but didn't have much luck with it. If you have got a i9 processor, you mught want to try XMR or other GPU resistant coins but again don't try solo mining ever.

comments.author: MetaMii
comments.body: Quote from: avikz on June 01, 2022, 07:18:59 PMQuote from: desouza420 on May 29, 2022, 04:10:36 PMHey everybodyis it a wise idea to use my gaming pc for mining?i am thinking of buying a mining rig but i want to wait till August and you all know the reasonand in the meantime i am thinking of using my PC for mining for a few monthsi have a GeForce 1050 TI using nicehash for miningany ideas for coins/pools or solo mining are welcome If you had thought about it back in 2009 to 2016, you would have became a millionaire by now. However, for now, your configuration is not suitable for mining anymore. So I would suggest you not to burn your system by mining. Rather get a mining rig for that purpose. I have a 1660ti and it just produces 27 mh/s. I have tried mining ETH using it but didn't have much luck with it. If you have got a i9 processor, you mught want to try XMR or other GPU resistant coins but again don't try solo mining ever. Your 1660ti should give you 30-32MH not 27MH, that's the type of hashrate you should get from a normal 1660 non ti and non Super, it's because you aren't using the right configuration or OC combinations. Use Trex miner and lock the core clock to 1300 using Hive OS and meme clock 1600-1900.

comments.author: devil2man
comments.body: With a 1050 you can try to mine aion, equilibria, conceal, uplexa with a certain yield but nothing will give you more profit than nicehash

comments.author: 0verseer
comments.body: Newbies learning mining by using their old cards is fine. His 1050ti could still be profitable if he found the right coin to mine. Of course, p/p won't be optimized but that should do for the learning experience. I remember back in the old days, I was mining the DGB coin with a 940m card. Yes, it was a mobile VGA on a laptop. I think I paid for electricity more than I make it back by selling DGB coin on bittrex and slowly reducing the life cycle of my laptop. But it was fun and it help me to learn the basics of setup .bat, command line for pools, and such.
